metadata.title: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome and Exercise
synonyms: systemic exertion intolerance disease (seid) cfids and exercise
chronic fatigue and immune dysfunction syndrome and exercise
anatomical location body part affected: Dysregulation has been observed in multiple diverse organ systems/endocrine, immune, muscular, and neurological
description: Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS),often also called myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME), is a medicallyunexplained condition characterized by widespread pain, persistent fatigue despite adequate rest, general malaise, and cognitive and mood complaints (18)
CFS likely involves complex dysregulation in multiple systems, as endocrine, immune, infectious, muscular, and neurological abnormalities have been noted
The Institute of Medicine has proposed that the diagnostic entity of CFS/ME be replaced with the name systemic exertion intolerance disease (SEID)(10)
Authors of a 2016 meta-analysis  (N = 159 persons with CFS [PwCFS]) found that the increase in fatigue measured 4 hours after acute exercise was significantly greater in PwCFS than controls(11)

Authors of a 2016 meta-analysis  of 8 RCTs (N = 1518 participants)found that most PwCFS had reduced fatigue after 12 to 26 weeks of exercise therapy, without serious risk of worsening long-term  outcomes(1)

The main therapeutic goal of exercise training in PwCFS is to improve functional capacity for ADLs without increasing persistent fatigue. Exercises should be closely supervised and self-paced  to minimize exacerbation of symptoms
For further discussion, see Clinical Review… Chronic Fatigue Syndrome; CINAHLTopic ID Number: T708481 or application of equipment . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures

ICD-10 codes.R53.82: chronic fatigue syndrome (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Inquire about any ongoing legal claims
presentation signs and symptoms: The presentation is highly variable, suggesting that CFS is a heterogenous condition.(6)However, a distinguishing feature is complaint of persistent overwhelming  fatigue that greatly reduces capacity for occupational, educational, social, or personal activities (including ADLs and recreation)

According to the U.S. CDC case definition, the diagnosis of CFS requires the following 2 criteria:(2) –Severe chronic fatigue for at least 6 months that is not relieved by rest and not due to medical or psychiatric conditions associated with fatigue as excluded by clinical diagnosis –Four or more of the following symptoms -Self-reported  impairment in short-term  memory or concentration severe enough to cause substantial reduction in previous level of occupational, educational, social, or personal activities -Psychological complaints of emotional lability, anxiety, depressive mood, and irritability -Sore throat that is frequent or recurring -Tender cervical or axillary lymph nodes -Muscle pain -Multi-joint  pain without swelling or redness -Headaches of a new type, pattern, or severity -Unrefreshing sleep, insomnia -Postexertional malaise (extreme, prolonged exhaustion and sickness following physically stressful activity) lasting more than 24 hours Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Monitor heart rate (HR) and blood pressure (BP), especially in patients who report lightheadedness/dizziness
Monitor for suicidal ideation, inform referring physician, and refer to psychologist and/or support groups(7)

causes: The etiology of CFS is unknown; most cases are considered idiopathic
Abnormal immunological findings suggest infectious agents (e.g., Epstein-Barr  virus [EBV], human herpesvirus 6[HHV-6],  and human parvovirus B19) may be contributing causes ofCFS (18)
The synonym ME suggests an inflammatory cause of heightened muscle pain, while the name SEID specifically indicatesthat exercise intolerance is an essential component of the disease
pathogenesis: The etiological basis and pathogenesis of CFS remain unknown.Proposed mechanisms of CFS include increased oxidativestress, B cell impairment, alterations to immunoglobulin numbers, and alterations to the CNS.(18)Common "triggers"include severe viral infections and emotional stress that involve immune dysfunction and elevated inflammatory cytokines

Authors of an RCT (n = 24 PwCFS and 18 healthy controls) in Australia found that 12 weeks of supervised exerciseimproved functional aerobic capacity and enhanced immunosurveillance, as indicated by increased natural killer cellactivation and degranulation markers. There was no significant change in symptoms(12)

Individuals with CFS are proposed to have an exaggerated pain response system due to chemical and structural changes inthe CNS. The exaggerated responses lead to what is known as “kindling,” which keeps the sensitized neurons stimulated(18)
risk factors: The estimated worldwide prevalence of CFS is 0.4% to 1%, including over 800,000 persons in the United States and240,000 in the United Kingdom(2)
Females have about 3 times the risk of males (19)
Age range: 30 to 55 years. Average age of onset is 37 years
Authors of a retrospective study from Taiwan correlated an increased risk of CFS with migraine(9)

overall contraindications precautions: Modify the intensity and duration of physical activity/exercise to avoid postexertional malaise
Avoid exercise training that patient perceives as stressful (especially prolonged and/or intense)
Respect patient’s complaints of fatigue and pain
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Monitor heart rate (HR) and blood pressure (BP), especially in patients who report lightheadedness/dizziness
Monitor for suicidal ideation, inform referring physician, and refer to psychologist and/or support groups(7)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Idiopathic onset; in some cases associated with viral infection (18)

course of treatment.medical management: Standard treatment is mainly palliative.(2) Document treatment for various symptoms on presentation that were satisfied in the case description (see Presentation , above)
course of treatment.medications: Supportive (not curative) agents include medications for anxiety and depression analgesics anti-inflammatories sleep aids various nutritional supplements that may reduce fatigue and increase energy
diagnostic tests completed: Complete blood count with differential WBC count
Chemistry panel  BUN, creatinine, electrolytes, glucose, calcium, phosphorus, alanine aminotransferase (ALT), alkaline phosphatase, total protein, albumin
tuberculin skin testing, Lyme serology, HIV serology
EKG/ECG if chest pain is present
vitamin D levels are often low, bone density testing for osteoporosis
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational therapy, physical therapy, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), specialist medical care (SMC), graded exercise therapy (GET), or adaptive pacing therapy for CFS and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: List daily activities associated with increased or lessened symptoms
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document symptoms that satisfy case definition (see Presentation , above)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document unrefreshing sleep, hours of sleep, and quality of sleep(2)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, hypotension, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document whether the patient experiences shortness of breath or dyspnea Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document dates of chronic fatigue diagnosed in past
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including fibromyalgia, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms that are ongoing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What are the physical demands of occupational or recreational activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document level of functional independence based on the assistance needed in ADLs
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess for need, appropriate fit, and appropriate use of devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance reactions in standing
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Confirm that peripheral pulses are present in all limbsReview normal gross movement during transfers and functional tasks using the upper extremities (e.g., reaching, pulling, pushing, holding) and lower extremities (steps, squatting, kneeling, kicking). Assess with the FIM and Short Form Health Survey (SF-36)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for abnormal patterns in gait that appear inefficient
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manually scan strength in functional tasks (e.g., pushing, pulling, sit-up,  squatting) to identify general weaknesses. Assess weak muscle groups using MMT. Assess handgrip strength with a hand dynamometer
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess posture in standing and during gait
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess flexibility, especially of lower extremities. (Tight muscles may contribute to inefficient movement patterns.) Screen for functional ROM of trunk and extremities during the prescribed exercisesAssess deep tendon reflexes
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Chalder Fatigue Scale(20) –Medical Outcomes Study Short-Form  (SF-36)  for HRQoL –State-Trait  Anxiety Inventory (STAI) for anxiety levels –Checklist Individual Strength (CIS) Subscale for fatigue

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in clinical decision making

Tailor the exercise prescription for the patient’s functional ability and exertional symptoms. Inform patients that exercise training will likely exacerbate their symptoms at first and provide regular feedback about postexertional symptoms
Monitor perceived exertion during exercise and postexertional malaise using V AS
Ensure close supervision with instruction throughout exercise therapy and functional training sessions
Provide the patient with a thorough orientation to using therapeutic exercise equipment with adequate warm-up  time to help reduce apprehension about exercise
Modify exercise for tolerance and prevention of postexertional malaise in either aerobic or resistance training
Clinicians should follow the exercise guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician

Evidence is lacking to support the use of electrotherapeutic modalities in CFS. Modalities are indicated only when prescribed by the referring physician or to treat associated musculoskeletal conditions
Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment regarding the use of modalities

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: CFS/impaired physical functioning, including limitations in ADLs; reduced aerobic fitness and strength, generalized fatigue, myalgia, and a constellation of psychophysical symptoms
assessment plan of care.rule out: Infectious diseases Neuroendocrine disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, Cushing disease, diabetes) Psychiatric disorders (e.g., depression, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, dementia, anorexia nervosa) Neurologic disease (e.g., multiple sclerosis, narcolepsy) Rheumatologic disease (e.g., fibromyalgia, polymyalgia rheumatica, Sjögren syndrome)
prognosis: Total relief of symptoms with normalization of functional capacity is unlikely in most adults with CFS(2)

According to a research study conducted in the Netherlands, graded exercise therapy(GET) has detrimental health effectsfor≥ 50% of patients, according to patient surveys. As a result, GET was not recommended by the authors(15)
Authors of a 2015 systematic review of 8 RCTs found that most PwCFS may benefit from exercise therapy, without serious risk of worsening long-term outcomes(1)
Authors of a study (N = 26 women with CFS) in Serbia found that GET can improve HRQoL (SF-36)  and decrease anxiety levels (STAI). Patients were assessed before and after 12 weeks of GET(4)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Psychologist for counseling/cognitive behavioral therapy/support groups Physician for intractable pain Occupational therapist for assessment of instrumental ADLs Acupuncturist Nutritionist for dietary counseling
other considerations: Authors of an RCT (N = 134 PwCFS) in Norway found no significant differences in fatigue severity, self-efficacy,  or the physical and mental component summary of the SF-36  at 1-year  follow-up  between the group receiving a self-management program that included eight bi-weekly  meetings of 2.5 hours duration and the control group that received usual care(13)
treatment summary: For persons with CFS and comorbid fibromyalgia, CBT and GET were more effective in reducing the frequency of both joint and muscle pain than adaptive pacing therapy (APT) and SMC(5)

Exercise should be modified to improve tolerance on an individual basis. Use of the V AS and a subjective rating scale such as Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale may help to monitor perceived exertion, pain, and other reported symptoms(3)
Extend the cool-down  period and ask the patient to slow down gradually after exercise. Stopping suddenly may increase the risk of orthostatic hypotension and syncope in some cases

A research group in China found in an RCT (N = 150 PwCFS) that qigong (sixteen 1.5-hour  lessons over 9 consecutive weeks) improved subjective sleep quality and sleep latency compared to waitlist control group(14) –Qigong is a coordinated body-posture  and movement system incorporating breathing and meditation techniques for improving one’s health and spirituality

Authors of an RCT (N = 122 PwCFS) in the Netherlands found that MRT was more effective for reducing long-term fatigue compared CBT alone(8) –Initial treatment was 10 weeks, followed by follow-up  at 12 weeks and 52 weeks –Patients were randomized into the MRT (n = 62) or CBT (n = 60) groups –Ten weeks of MRT intervention consisted of the following: -PT sessions 1x/week: Co-treatment  with occupational therapy (OT) focusing on gradual progression of activities under close supervision -OT sessions 1x/week: similar to PT sessions and included co-treatment  with social worker and psychologist  -Psychologist focused on improving patients’ beliefs regarding illness symptoms, activity, self-expectations  and self-esteem,  and coping strategies -Meetings between interdisciplinary teams were scheduled to discuss patient progress -Total contact hours for MRT was 44.5 hours -A follow-up  phase at 12 weeks after the initial 10 weeks was planned. Patients were asked to return for 2 days to meet with a social worker and two therapists of their choice –CBT group incorporated behavioral and cognitive therapy with a psychologist. Patients were educated on changing negative beliefs about their symptoms, self-expectations,  and self-esteem.  Patients were also educated on adopting a regular sleep/wake cycle. Patients received a total of 16 sessions for 45–60 minutes during the 6 months –Primary outcome measures for this study were the CIS fatigue subscale and SF-36 to measure HRQoL –After 52 weeks, the MRT group showed significantly more improvement in CIS fatigue scores than the CBT group. HRQoL improved in both groups, but no between-group  significant difference in HRQoL was found

A multimodal rehabilitation program (MMR) can improve both the working memory and the physical and mental strength of patients experiencing exhaustion disorder (16) –Thirteen participants were randomized to either the MMR group + CBT (n = 6) or MMR + aerobic training group (n = 7) –The MMR + CBT group met once a week for 22 weeks for 3-hour  long sessions. CBT group focused on stress and recovery techniques, sleep, and coping with emotions –The MMR + aerobic training group performed their respective exercises 3x/week for 12 weeks and received a computerized cognitive training for at least 15–20 minutes a session. Aerobic exercise included indoor cycling for 40 minutes

Authors of a study conducted in the United Kingdom found that only a small percentage of patients with CFS experience benefits from CBT (8%–35%),  most have negative responses to GET (54%–74%),  and most favored pacing (scheduling periods of rest in day-to-day  activities) with the highest reported benefits (44%–82%)(17) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Generalized muscle pain and tightnessDecrease sensitivity to stretchingManual therapy _ Trial of gentle stretching and massage to address muscle tightnessGradually increase intensity and duration of soft-tissue workProvide patient with instructions for simple flexibility exercises Impaired physical functioning in daily activitiesImprove functional capacityTherapeutic exercises _ Trial of intermittent self-paced and brief aerobic and/or resistance exercise. Trial of walking at preferred speedGradual progression of intensity and duration of exercises according to patient toleranceDaily repetition of exercises, as tolerated _ Provide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions regarding functional activities that can be performed at home and correct use and/ or application of equipment .

maintenance or prevention: Continue exercises found effective and well-tolerated  to maintain physical functioning for ADLs
